awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Managing epidemics in wildlife with acquired resistance
awd_abstract_narration:
Infectious diseases pose a serious threat to many wild animals. While vaccination is a successful tool against diseases of humans and livestock, it is rarely used to control wildlife diseases. This is partly because of a poor understanding of immunity in wild animals and its impact across a large population. This award will address these gaps in knowledge by studying the immunity acquired by frogs against a fungus, Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis (Bd). Bd infection has caused a severe decline in frog numbers around the world. Recent studies have shown that frogs exposed to dead Bd become resistant to future infection. They suggest that the immune system of frogs can be harnessed to fight Bd. This award combines mathematical theory with laboratory and field experiments to understand the correlates of acquired resistance to Bd in frogs and assess the potential for managing outbreaks in wild populations by stimulating acquired resistance to the fungus. Results of this study will facilitate the development and testing of a novel, widely applicable theory for the management of epidemics in wildlife. Consequently, this work will help to curb losses of biodiversity. Researchers will share their results with groups working on frog conservation and provide multi-disciplinary training to a diverse group of scientists. Computer-based teaching tools that illustrate wildlife disease management through vaccination will be developed and made publicly available.
 
There is poor understanding of acquired resistance in wild animals and a scarcity of theory underlying wildlife vaccination. These gaps in physiology and ecology will be addressed in the current research using amphibians and the chytrid fungus, Bd.  Bd is selected for study because this pathogen contributes to global amphibian declines and the recent discovery that amphibians acquire immunological resistance following exposure to dead Bd. This award integrates mathematical theory with laboratory and field experiments to i) characterize the acquisition and maintenance of Bd resistance across host life stages, ii) evaluate the immunological mechanisms responsible for individual resistance and whether their presence predicts population-level outcomes, iii) determine if resistance can be induced in wild populations, and iv) if so, can this alter epidemics and host persistence in a whole-ecosystem experiment populations - an outcome of broad significance for wildlife conservation. This project links immunological mechanisms and individual-level traits to population- and community-level disease outcomes. It advances fundamental knowledge of host-parasite interactions while helping to curb disease-driven worldwide losses of biodiversity. Results of this research will be disseminated to conservation partners to help limit the spread of chytridiomycosis. This research will facilitate the training of a diverse group of scientists in physiology, ecology, and mathematical biology. Computer modules that illustrate general and amphibian-specific outcomes of disease management via acquired immunity will be integrated into teaching and made publicly available.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Emerging infectious diseases pose one of the greatest threats to global biodiversity. Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis (Bd), for example, is arguably one of the deadliest pathogens on earth in terms of number of extinctions and it has been associated with the loss of hundreds of amphibian species worldwide. This is a wide spread aquatic fungus with other non-amphibian hosts and possible ecosystem reservoirs, and so it is difficult to eradicate or clear it from the ecosystem. With this NSF funded research project we developed an effective prophylaxis that can be used to provide protection for amphibians against this devastating pathogen.

            Preliminary experiments found that we could provide protection to amphibians by exposing amphibians to and clearing them of the live infection repeatedly. While this was effective it was not safe for at-risk species and could not be utilized in the field. We then determined we could provide the same protective benefit to amphibians by exposing them repeatedly to the killed fungus, which meant that we did not have to utilize the live fungus in the process. In order for this prophylaxis to be effective and implementable we needed the process to be to provide protection across amphibian species and life stages (tadpole, metamorph and adult), to be epidemiologically safe, efficient, and effective.

We determined that we could provide protection across multiple species of amphibians, including the Pacific chorus frog (Pseudacris regilla) and Cuban treefrogs (Osteopilus septentrionalis). Pacific chorus frogs are particularly important because they have been identified as an important and widespread reservoir host for the fungus and they are known to facilitate Bd persistence in the field. We also found that the Bd metabolite prophylaxis provided protection across all three life stages. Reducing Bd loads in the most abundant life stages, example the tadpoles, in the field is particularly advantageous because it would allow managers to dose a waterbody directly, providing protection to a large proportion of the population.

We refined the prophylaxis protocol through a series of experiments. We determined that the water-soluble chemicals (metabolites) Bd produces are the effective component of the prophylaxis. While the presence of killed zoospores did not cause harm, they did not provide protection themselves and they did not increase how effective the prophylaxis was. Therefore, we recommend using a Bd metabolite solution with no cellular components of Bd at all. This is particularly important because the Bd metabolite prophylaxis is considered an epidemiologically safe prophylaxis when made properly because there is no risk of infection. We determined the most effective prophylaxis was created by flash freezing live Bd culture and then straining it to remove the physical fungal components (as compared to strained then frozen). We crossed prophylaxis concentration by duration of exposure and found that even low concentrations for short durations were effective. Interestingly, increased Bd metabolite prophylaxis concentration did not confer additional protection and so we suggest a protocol using a low concentration for a short exposure duration. Additionally, evidence indicates that the metabolites produced by Bd may alter the immune system, and while the prophylaxis exposure provides protection quickly, we found that a two-week lag period prior to infection exposure was most protective. All of these experiments repeatedly found that exposure to the Bd metabolite prophylaxis reduced Bd load and in some, but not all, cases reduced prevalence compared to the controls as well.

We developed the Bd metabolite prophylaxis directly from live strains of Bd and for most of our work we utilized the strain most closely associated with the amphibian species we were working with. We found that there were differential effects when using a prophylaxis developed from a different strain than the infection strain, and so it is important any future work take strain into consideration. We also determined that there was no benefit or harm in exposure to the prophylaxis after amphibians were infected with the fungus. This is particularly important for field implementation safety because our prophylaxis does not exacerbate established infections.          

We have begun to develop our understanding of how this metabolite prophylaxis provides protection to amphibians and determined that exposure to the prophylaxis alters the hosts’ microbiome. Specifically, increased prophylactic concentration and exposure duration was associated with increased anti-Bd bacteria on the host skin. Additionally, in behavioral trials we found that some species, but not all, were capable of avoiding Bd after an exposure to an initial infection and that they utilized the metabolites as cues to avoid Bd.

Prophylactic regimes like the one we developed with this grant provide a promising path forward for protecting wildlife against pathogenic organisms. Our research enhances our ability to address the detrimental consequences of disease outbreaks among natural populations in many systems and provide deep insight and application to worldwide amphibian declines associated with chytridiomycosis.
